comments: n/a
N/A
It was a live lecture/seminar with breakout rooms and occasional asynchronous recording.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about German Fairy tales while simultaneously improving my German skills, being accustomed to a seminar-style college class with readings, and how to conduct a research project.
I greatly expanded my German vocabulary and learned how to better analyze texts with profound culturally and historically significant subject matter.
analyzing German fairy tales, reading German academic secondary texts
My German reading, writing, and speaking improved.

The reading is different than in a more "modern" L5 class - you learn a lot of german fairy-tale specific vocabulary, and also you take a deep dive into a few famous scholars on german fairy tale literature.
There is an alternate writing and speaking class each week, which is very helpful. You learn how to model different styles of writing (i.e. using german fairy tale specific grammar and vocab).

In general, I learned a lot about fairy tales obviously (and there's so much more to learn than I knew!). Each week we discussed different themes, such as authors of Fairy tales, religion, violence, family relationships, the portrayal of women, etc.
I learned more about German grammatical structure and increased my vocabulary. Also, of course, I read many German fairy tales and some secondary texts about them.
Continued to develop my german knowledge

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was amazing. The information we covered was very interesting and fun -- I like how we combined our readings of secondary texts with readings of the fairy tales. The creative tasks were quite fun, and all expectations for the assignments were communicated well. I loved my research project, and I liked how it was so open -- it let me do whatever I wanted.
The subject of the course is fascinating, and Prof. Schenker is a very kind and engaging professor as well. The course had no weaknesses.
Theresa is an amazing professor, very understanding, engaging, welcoming, and responsive to feedback/questions, fairy tales are nice to read & all the tasks/assignments are well-defined

This was a great course.  the combination of simpler fairy tales with complex secondary texts allowed me to work on both my colloquial simple German and get introduced in a lower stakes way to reading academic German texts.

Theresa adapts very well to students of different levels and backgrounds (even at the L5 point) and the class encouraged learning in all students. The course gives students the opportunity to learn about a certain style and usage of German, rather than just modern-day German, and this was appropriately challenging and also expanded students' flexibility within the language.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: this course was great even on zoom.
The small seminar format with breakout rooms was very conducive to getting a lot of speaking practice in, and I also felt closer with other students.
Theresa was very experienced and adept with Zoom, and the class was well executed virtually. One improvement would be if Theresa were to have regular open office hours.
It was all great but it would have been convenient to have one consistent zoom link

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This course is so fun and interesting. We learn about fairy tales and have really fun discussions. This course is awesome if you want to learn more about German culture/literature, and I loved seeing how many roles fairy tales can play.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! The course's subject matter is very interesting and relatable, and Prof. Schenker is excellent at keeping students engaged and making the class a great environment for learning.
Definitely recommend for an L5 course, any class with Theresa will be amazing, will definitely take more time to read secondary texts if you're not a native speaker but it's doable
Definitely- it was quite engaging!
Absolutely I would recommend this course.  Theresa is a fantastic instructor, and her feedback is always really helpful.  This course helped me in reading, speaking, and cultural knowledge.

YES!!!! Take this class. Theresa is a wonderful professor, and the material is so interesting. I learned about so many things I never even considered, and it gives so much perspective to the stories we read and tell today. The fairy tales themselves are fun to read, the class itself is well structured and moves quickly, and all of the assignments are purposeful (there is never any "busy work"). This class DOES require time and energy, but Theresa never expects (and never would want) you to compromise your happiness and health for it.

Yes! Theresa is a great professor and the course is fun and interesting. The secondary texts are sophisticated and challenging, but the fairy tales are simple and engaging, so the student can learn German in different ways and contexts.
Great course if you want to develop your german skulls and professor Schenker is amazing
